Description: Corroded straight iron bar of oval to peanut-shaped cross-section with a loop at each end, possibly the mouthpiece of bridle-bit.
Curator's comments: One of the "horses' bits" which are "with holes for the attachment, as in fig. 2", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 2. Other items from Tell Dafana considered as bridle-bits: London, BM, EA 23968 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 1), Cairo, EM, JE 27378 (lost), Boston, MFA 87.515 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77). Interpretation of London, BM, EA 23965, 23966 and Boston, MFA, 87.516 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 5, 5a, 6), as well as London, BM, EA 23981, is more questionable.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 2)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.47, p.78, p.185, pl.27)
Condition: Corroded and incomplete (part of one loop broken and missing); broken in three pieces reunited
